channel.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
channel.description:
[b]Article from the Sun newspaper:[/b]
"Google is being probed for secretly collecting personal data from millions of Brits home computers using its Street View cars.
The IT giant is under fire over software in its vehicles which captured emails, documents, texts and photos from unsecured Wi-Fi networks.
US investigators have seen internal emails and documents which show the Street View team was alerted to the software's privacy breaching powers. Britain's Information Commissioner's Office which previously concluded any information was collected "inadvertently", is studying new evidence."
[b]Well, if you can't trust Google, who [i]can[/i] you trust?[/b]

@angelofdeath396 wrote:

sarcastically “Oh no, I’m scared! Now google is planning to collect all that data for an evil terror plot”.

I mean, seriously, It’s not that much of a big deal tbh.

  • I DONT THINK that its a major threat.

item.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Google knows what videos you watch, what you search for (by extension what you browse for), and with it’s gigantic network of sites probably does know more than any other company. And you give all of this information willing, so yea I don’t see big deal.

Read full topic

item.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Either way I wouldn’t really care. I’m sure Google knows more about me than anyone else in the world.

Read full topic

item.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Published: 19 Nov 2010

Explains why I haven’t heard of it. But no, I suggest you read the news post before making assumptions. They collected email information and the websites people visited, which now is pretty much obsolete considering they have a pretty decent monopoly over the market. Stop being so anarchist, they only collected data passing through the network at the time they passed through, so unless people were all uploading their sensitive documents to a website at the time your argument is invalid and pointless.

Read full topic

item.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

Davidi2:

If this was real it would be much larger news, as I’m pretty sure that’s a felony that could get you arrested here in the USA. Why should we trust you with no news source?

Because I typed it from the paper, but here: http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3236787/Google-deletes-Street-View-data.html

Rodger is right, but there are some things you use a computer for, for private things, such as private documents etc. You wouldn’t want a corporation with their hands on your private stuff, because why do they need it? It’s all about control and power.

Google pretty much has the entire planet’s knowledge and thoughts at their fingertips.

Read full topic

@zyle1992 wrote:

This is old news. It happened here too. All they said was “Well, we didn’t intend on gathering personal information, but it was inadvertently collected when we were scanning for open WIFI networks like Starbucks, etc”

item.title: Google Breaches Privacy Laws
item.dc:creator: @Sinned Sinned
item.description:
@Sinned wrote:

Article from the Sun newspaper:

"Google is being probed for secretly collecting personal data from millions of Brits home computers using its Street View cars.

The IT giant is under fire over software in its vehicles which captured emails, documents, texts and photos from unsecured Wi-Fi networks.

US investigators have seen internal emails and documents which show the Street View team was alerted to the software’s privacy breaching powers. Britain’s Information Commissioner’s Office which previously concluded any information was collected “inadvertently”, is studying new evidence."

Well, if you can’t trust Google, who can you trust?
